intro: Conchocarpus jirajaranus, commonly known as the red mangrove fruit, is a species native to tropical regions of the Indo-Pacific. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive red, fleshy fruits that contain a single, elongated seed. The plant thrives in brackish water environments, often found in mangrove ecosystems. Its botanical features include a woody stem, opposite leaves, and a unique reproductive system that aids in seed dispersal. The species plays an important ecological role in coastal habitats by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial organisms.
